unnormalised: Okay, so someone asked about the future of online learning in India? Well, let me tell you, it's looking pretty bright. My cousin, Priya, is prepping for her NEET exams using Byju's and she says it's way better than just relying on her coaching classes. Plus, she saves like, 2 hours of commute time! She used to travel all the way to Vidya Mandir Classes, which is a total pain, especially during the Delhi summers.

unnormalised: The whole EdTech scene is booming, right? Think Unacademy, Vedantu, Simplilearn. A lot of folks are opting for these courses. My neighbour’s kid even cracked IIT-JEE after enrolling in a 1 yr course from FIITJEE E-School, that cost him ₹ 2,50,000! And it’s not just for entrance exams. People are learning new skills, like coding, data science (Avg. salary for a data scientist is around Rs. 8 LPA these days according to Naukri.com!), and even foreign languages online. I saw an ad for a French course on Coursera for just $49.99!

unnormalised: I think the key is the flexibility. You can learn at your own pace, anytime, anywhere. Plus, you get access to top-notch teachers from all over the country, maybe even the world! And with the Jio revolution, internet access is becoming more affordable, even in smaller towns. My uncle in Patna can now easily access online classes, which was impossible 5 yrs ago. He is learning about "Digital Marketing" from some XYZ academy (cost Rs 15000) and aims to kick start his own business by Jan 2025.

unnormalised: Overall, I'd say online learning is here to stay and it's only going to get bigger and better. It's definitely changing the way we learn and opening up opportunities for millions of students across India. Just make sure to do your research before signing up for any course, okay? Don't just jump on the bandwagon because some influencer is promoting it. Good luck!
